Slightly malty sweet through a roasty underscore of a toasted toffee to caramel breadiness all around. column8: ending crisp and dry with a nice touch of coffee and nuts which lingers for a good time. As it warms it picks up notes of plum fruityness and ginger bread dough just before the finish. Great subtle flavors that mix and build together nicely. Feel is a solid medium body with a pleasnt carbonation and a nice little finish of crispy dryness. A fine drinkin' beer and at only 4.5% makes for a excellent session brew. This goes to show you that not every beer needs to slap you in the face. There's something to be said about being able to appreciate mild beers and this is the beer in which to do it with. Nice work

column3: this is probably the big milestone so far. 100 was good but easily achievable
column4: 200 pretty much the same with the subsequent centuries becoming more difficult as beer literally ran dry. So now 500 arrives with a beer that I am told only had this number as its brew run. This means only 300 litres of this has been made available to the world. Is it worth the SGD25 (AUD21/USD15) for the 640ml bottle? Does the fact that there are instructions that as I empty the bottle I can blow into it and get the sound of notes made famous by Ashkenazy? Who you ask? Bloody Philistines. Vladimir Ashkenazy has often been quoted as saying that for him music is indivisible. This conviction is borne out by his passionate engagement with so many different aspects of music-making
column5: whether as conductor
column6: piano recitalist or chamber musician or as the architect of large-scale projects encompassing the full range of musical activities. This was bottle number 250 of the 500 so hopes are high. Is this the first 5?? Aah nup. It is a good beer

column3: United States;Helles / Dortmunder Export;Victory Brewing Company (ABV);From May 2007 I received this in a trade with jwc215...thanks
column4: Joe! This pours from 12oz bottle(best by Jun 19 07) a clear
column5: bubbly straw gold colour with a large head of foam. It settles down after a while but stays for the entire session as a fine layer and there's lacing. The smell hasa pretty hoppy aroma mixed in with some malty tones. The taste on first sip has a nice hoppy presence... I'm getting some lemon zest. Further sips in and there's some non sweetish malt and bread there but they are on the light side. It finishes crisp and clean and makes for a good thirst quencher. The body is light as is the carbonation. I like this one and it has a good German feel to it. Bottom line: This is a good Lager...no bells or whistles
column6: just a good solid Lager. I'd drink it again.

column3: United States;Belgian Ale - Pale / Golden;Old Dominion Brewing Company (AB InBev);I had this on tap at the Old Dominion brewpub. Its came out a deep brown color with a slight beige head that left little in the way of lacing. The smell was of sweet fruit and caramel malt. The taste is very similar with sweet caramel malt being most noticeable and dark fruits also having a strong presence. There were definitely root beer like qualities that were in the taste and smell that made it an interesting beer. Mouthfeel was medium with a creamy texture. This was definitely drinkable as the lighter than normal body for the style allows this to go down much quicker. Not the best dubbel but an interesting twist that is solid.

column3: Germany;Zwickelbier/Kellerbier/Landbier;Schlo�brauerei Stelzer Fattigau;50cl bottle pours with a clear gold effervescent gold body that supports a thin near white head of regenerating foam. The aroma offers up a mix of spicy to grassy to a touch lime like hoppiness with mild grainy malt notes and a sliver or two of almond nuttiness underneath. The taste hits first with a pleasing spicy to grassy to a bit floral hoppiness across the palate where there�s a good dose of both bittering hops and flavoring hoppiness. To midway mild sugar malt notes are noticed that roll into a slightly grainy malt to nutty sensation but overall this remains firmly hoppy from front to back. Nice hoppy flavor where the flat sense of the zwickel body is right there into the finish. Nice zwickeled pils. I like it. I wish in the summer there were more Zwickels around to try.

column3: United States;Stout - Oatmeal;Otter Creek Brewing;From Aug 2006 Poured from 12oz bottle a clear very dark brown with amber hues and a large head of foam that dissipated slowly leaving a fine layer with good lacing. The smell is all roasty and toasty and has big notes of hot chocolate. The taste is really big. Roasted malt and a semi sweet molasses grab my taste buds right from the go and there's a hop bitterness that doesn't show up for me until near the finish but it does give the over all presentation of this oatmeal stout the proper umphh. Bottom line: This is a sample of the style that everyone should try given the chance.

column4: Stow-on-the-Wold. Old notes from circa 1999. On a more recent visit to this pub I confirmed with the landlords and some regulars
column5: one of whom used to work for the brewery
column6: that this beer is definitely discontinued. They carried on making it for the one pub in the estate (I forget which) that took it but gave up a couple of years ago. So I�ll break my usual rule and rate from old notes as this historic beer is unlikely to be seen again. Dark brown with a reddish tinge. A fruity and slightly woody mild

column5: that I had to be sure of grabbing one before they sold out. Though I didn�t want to sample the whole range - the other more regular beers I would save for a visit to Stow in the future. This dark mild has some brown fringes and a light and refreshing body. There is some soft coffee aroma and some cough syrup flavours. There�s a clean and soft acidity in the finish alongside a faint licorice. A nice

column3: England;Mild Ale;Donnington Brewery;Cask Conditioned at The Queens Head
column4: Stow on the Wold
column5: Gloucs. Donningtons Brewery is about as traditional as you can get. The Arkell family split in the 19th Century and Thomas Arkell bought a working watermill near Stow on the Wold to brew his beers
column6: in the 21st century Claude carries on the family name. The brewery is idyllic
column7: pobably the most beautiful brewery in the world
column8: a wild claim I know. High in cotswold country
column9: the waterwheel still drives some of the pumps and gristmills around the brewery. The brewery owns 15 pubs in a tight area around the northern cotswolds and they are all pretty much traditionally run country pubs with domino's
column11: and all just sell Donningtons beers
column12: no selling out to marketing fads here! Claude only sells his beers through his own pubs too
column13: although a couple of casks have made it to beer festivals if the organisers are prepared to pick them up and deliver the empties back directly to the brewery. Incidentally
column14: this is the only way to get a look around as no visitors are allowed. The beer is a pretty standard mild and is the rarest of the pretty rare range of beers. There is a plummy fruitiness with a little spicey note. A short sweet finish. But with Donningtons its not all about the beer
column15: its the whole package that makes it wonderful.

column3: Germany;Helles / Dortmunder Export;Brauerei Schwelm;"(33cl bottle) Pale golden colour with diminishing white foam. Sweet malty nose; light to medium bodied; Sweetmalty
column4: slightly papery taste with a shy bitter hoppy finish.This one is a recreation of a former widespread beer
column5: once brewed in Bochum and Recklinghausen until 1980. I had the opportunity to ask some older people about their memory of Schlegel and all of them told me it was awful. Brewed with cheap raw material
column6: it was an industrial beer for industrial people during the period of heavy industries in the Ruhr area; it was rather to quench the thirst of masses of coal miners and steel workers cheap and quick than to be enjoyed. Now we have this �private� labelled recreation
column7: which is very expensive for a 330 ml longneck bottle
column9: representing right the opposite of the old clientele."

column4: you don�t get IBU�s like this from Nugget hops! I�d guess Columbus or Chinook. (3.7). UPDATE 11/2006: On tap at the Crescent Moon Christmas Beer tasting. I�m told that this year�s Festivale is 9.0% ABV. It pours amber orange with a huge beige head. Has a fruity aroma with lots of candy sweet bubblegum smells. Very hoppy grapefruit. It is strong. The palate is slightly harsh. This is a great beer. (4.3) UPDATE 2007: On tap at the Crescent Moon. The brewer calls this a braggot this year! It is a very muddy dark amber appearance with a medium white head. The honey aroma is very mild and subtle for the style. This is slightly smoky. This is certainly sweet and even a bit toungue coating with waxiness. This is not as strong a beer as it was last year
column5: but the honey flavor is definitely pronounced. However
column6: the homebrew braggots that I have tried are usually 50% honey and this is a far cry from that. My rating for this is 3.4. UPDATE 2009: Again a different recipe for this year. This batch is an Imperial Steam Beer. ABV of 7%. I definitely get an infusion of cherries in the flavor. Pretty unique.
